name: CALORIE - Taste of Remembering
description:
Wistful Sunday mornings over chai and biscuits listening to the pattering of rain.
Roasted rotis and sharing fragrant curries around a dining table.
Goldeny sweet jalebes that capture the rich lights of festivals. Memories of food is more than its taste.

Join us on a walkthrough of Calorie where we explore food as nostalgia! Through art, stories, and interactive moments, we will explore the meals we once ignored, the flavors we miss the most, and the small rituals that quietly shaped us.

Come for the stories, stay to colour.

name: Prompt Kitchen
description:
How much is a quarter teaspoon? How do you fold in cheese?

Recipes rely heavily on verbal instructions, and following them is often confusing. The Interaction Design Team from the National Institute of Design (NID) is reimagining how recipes are communicated. In this workshop, participants will generate custom recipe templates that are tangible, paper-based visual layouts for the ingredients and steps. They’ll delve into prompt engineering and recipe visualisation and ultimately design an interactive and spatial recipe. So that the next time you’re in the kitchen, following a recipe feels intuitive and fun, not confusing.

The workshop is designed for anyone interested in cooking from beginners to home cooks.

name: Know Your Food
description:
What’s in your food?

From food labels to nutrition myths to healthy diets, this quiz puts your food and nutrition knowledge to the test. It is designed to spark conversation around how marketing, cultural beliefs, and experiences that shape our nutrition knowledge. Come on your own or with friends, you’ll be grouped for a beginner-friendly food trivia experience.

name: Namma Ganita: Women of Mathematics in Bengaluru
description:
What does it mean to be a mathematician today?

From their favorite equations to what drew them to the field, Women Mathematicians from Bengaluru share their journeys and speak about all things mathematics.

Participants are invited to interact with mathematicians: ask questions, follow curiosities, and explore mathematics beyond textbooks. The event highlights the human side of doing mathematics by reflecting on the challenges women have faced and the research they pursue today.

Presented alongside Women of Mathematics, a photographic exhibition featuring 20 international women mathematicians curated by mathematician Sylvie Paycha and photographer Noel Tovia Matoff. It aims is to encourage young women to pursue careers in mathematics and theoretical physics, fields in which women remain underrepresented globally.

name: Does the Body Count Calories?
description:
How does the body count calories, and are all calories truly equal?

In an age of calorie counters, fitness watches, and food labels, energy seems easy to measure and neatly quantified. Yet what happens inside the body is far more complex. In this talk, Prof. Ullas Kolthur Seetharam from the Advanced Research Unit on Metabolism, Development, and Aging (ARUMDA) looks beyond weight and BMI to examine how nutrition, metabolism, and body composition shape our health.

Drawing on ARUMDA's research, he unpacks how the body processes food, senses energy needs, and adapts to growth, activity, and aging. He explores why calories are not all equal, how energy expenditure is regulated beyond what labels tell us, and what body composition reveals that body weight alone cannot. Bridging molecular biology, technology, and public health, the talk connects scientific insights to everyday questions around diet, growth, obesity, undernutrition, and metabolic disease. Offering a research-based view of how our bodies manage energy in this ever-changing food landscape.

This workshop explores the themes of ‘EAT’ & ‘DIGEST’ in relation to Science Gallery Bengaluru’s Exhibition CALORIE.

name:
Educator Workshop: 
Interdisciplinary Thinking In Practice
description:
Click here to [register]! 

Learning is often presented as distinct, neatly defined subjects.
Interdisciplinary thinking integrates them, opening up a word that is complex, interconnected, and full of surprises!

The Educator Workshop is a full-day immersive workshop for educators from across the city, to explore new ideas, think across disciplines, and reimagine learning together. Because the future of education is becoming increasingly interdisciplinary.

What to expect?
> Experience our exhibition-season CALORIE, where ideas from science, art, design, and society intersect.
> Unpack interdisciplinarity through hands-on activities and reflective discussions.
> Explore NCERT topics through a fresh lens.
> Collaborate in small groups to design practical ideas for sparking interdisciplinarity in the classroom. 
> Present your insights in a lively pitching session.

Who is this for?
Educators and teachers across subjects (Classes 7–12) who value curiosity, inquiry, and exploring ideas across disciplines.


Come, be a learner for a day.
Connect with fellow educators.
Return inspired—with practical tools and renewed energy for teaching.

name: What Makes You Up? Understanding Your Body’s Composition
description:
What does the scale really tell us about our bodies?

In this workshop, Prof. Ullas Kolthur decodes our weight, looking at fat, muscle, and body water to better understand how our bodies store and use energy. Using a portable body composition analyser, he explores how nutrition, calories, and metabolism are measured, and where these measurements fall short.

Drawing on both scientific research and lived experiences, the workshop invites participants to look beyond the scale and rethink what these numbers mean for health and nutrition. 

This workshop explores the themes of ‘EAT’ & ‘DIGEST’ in relation to Science Gallery Bengaluru’s Exhibition CALORIE.

name: Eat, Read, Think
description:
Eat, Read, Think is a reading circle run by Science Gallery Bengaluru, bringing together curious minds to explore ideas through literature and conversation. Readings will be themed around the current exhibition season, CALORIE, exploring humanity's fraught and intimate relationship with food through readings inspired by the many exhibits present throughout the gallery. Eat, Read, Think welcomes young people from all walks of life to gather for conversations that connect science, culture and society.

For the fifth session of the reading circle will focus on the 'Whats For Dinner Exhibit?'. We will be reading from 'A World of Equals: A Textbook On Gender' by Susie Tharu, A. Suneetha and Uma Maheswari Bhrugubanda.
